TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UniqueConstraint extends System.Data.Constraint

Attribute.AttributeName: System.ComponentModel.Editor("Microsoft.VSDesigner.Data.Design.UniqueConstraintEditor, Microsoft.VSDesigner, Version=10.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a", "System.Drawing.Design.UITypeEditor, System.Drawing, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")

Docs.summary: Represents a restriction on a set of columns in which all values must be unique.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The UniqueConstraint is enforced on a single column (or columns) to ensure that a primary key value is unique.
Constraints are not enforced unless the <xref:System.Data.DataSet.EnforceConstraints%2A> property is set to `true`.
When the a <xref:System.Data.DataSet> is merged with a second <xref:System.Data.DataSet>, constraints are not enforced until all merges are completed.
## Examples The following example adds a UniqueConstraint to a <xref:System.Data.DataSet> and sets the <xref:System.Data.DataSet.EnforceConstraints%2A> property to `true`.
[!CODE [Classic WebData UniqueConstraint Example#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_ADO.NET/Classic WebData UniqueConstraint Example#1)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks This constructor is provided for design time support in the Visual Studio .NET environment. <xref:System.Data.UniqueConstraint> objects created by using this constructor must then be added to the collection via <xref:System.Data.ConstraintCollection.AddRange%2A>. Columns with the specified names must exist at the time the method is called, or if <xref:System.Data.DataTable.BeginInit%2A> has been called prior to calling this constructor, the columns with the specified names must exist at the time that <xref:System.Data.DataTable.EndInit%2A> is called.

Docs.returns: `true`, if the contraints are equal; otherwise, `false`.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Two constraints are equal if they constrain the same columns.
## Examples The following example compares two UiqueConstraint objects.
[!CODE [Classic WebData UniqueConstraint.Equals Example#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_ADO.NET/Classic WebData UniqueConstraint.Equals Example#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public bool IsPrimaryKey { get; }
.property instance bool IsPrimaryKey

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether or not the constraint is on a primary key.
Docs.value: `true`, if the constraint is on a primary key; otherwise, `false`.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A table usually includes a primary key that ensures every row is unique. In some tables, the primary key may be made up of more than one column. For example, a primary key for a table containing names might be made up of both the first and last names as well. To create a primary key with more than one column, set the Columns property to an array of DataColumn objects.
## Examples The following example checks the IsPrimaryKey property.
[!CODE [Classic WebData UniqueConstraint.IsPrimaryKey Example#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_ADO.NET/Classic WebData UniqueConstraint.IsPrimaryKey Example#1)]
